references: We conduct comparisons between FedCT and existing methods, categorized into three groups: 1) local training without federated learning, SOLO; 2) federated learning (FL) methods without cross-training, including FedAvg [2], FedProx [8], MOON [13], FedDC [11], FedASAM [61], FedProc [18], FedDecorr [27], FedIOD [62]; 3) FL methods with cross-training, including FedExg [15] and PGCT [17]. references: As depicted in Table IV, inconsistency-based broadcasting results in poor performance. This could be due to the disparities among the knowledge, which hinder the model from fitting data from multiple sources simultaneously.

references: Table V illustrates that FedCT outperforms existing cross-training methods in all settings. This highlights the effectiveness of FedCT in various data-heterogeneous scenarios. It is worth noting that FedFTG achieves greater accuracy improvement in significant data-heterogeneous scenarios with β=0.05𝛽0.05\beta=0.05. Moreover, as the degree of data heterogeneity decreases, i.e., as β𝛽\beta increases, all methods show an increasing trend in accuracy.

references: This section investigates the communication rounds required by different methods to achieve the target test accuracy. Table VI reports the results. FedCT achieves the best results on both datasets, which reduces the round number required by baseline methods in all scenarios. This further indicates that alleviating the global knowledge forgetting problem can foster the learning of superior federated model. Notably, FedCTFedAvg achieves an acceleration ratio close to 4 on the CIFAR10, which demonstrating significantly higher communication efficiency compared to existing baseline methods.
